item.title: Coords
item.dc:creator: @x_blitz_x x blitz x
item.description:
@x_blitz_x wrote:

[quote=“wat72, post:12, topic:259800”][quote author=x blitz x link=topic=343063.msg2650675#msg2650675 date=1233511590]

[quote author=wat72 link=topic=343063.msg2650673#msg2650673 date=1233511456]

[quote author=x blitz x link=topic=343063.msg2650666#msg2650666 date=1233511147]

[quote author=wat72 link=topic=343063.msg2650633#msg2650633 date=1233509703]

Make a new command, then use System.out.println or the sendMessage method to printout the absX and absY integers.
[/quote]No, you should call integers variables.

No, they are intergers.
[/quote]Yes, but you call them variables because they are variables. Just like voids and anything else with brackets are called methods because they are methods.

Not everything with brackets is a method, and there’s no such thing as “voids”, void is a return type.
[/quote]No, void isn’t a return type it’s a non-primitive datatype, and datatypes with brackets are called methods. A void can’t be a return type because it doesn’t return anything.

void is a return type, it’s a return type of null. Also you clearly said,

and anything else with brackets are called methods

Which is false, because a class has brackets and a class is not a method.
[/quote]I corrected myself and said that any datatype with brackets is called a method. A void “may” be a return type, but it’s also a non-primitive datatype.[/quote]
Has brackets? Also has a datatype. Not a method.

int[] intArray = {5};

Read full topic

item.title: Coords
item.dc:creator: @wat72 wat72
item.description:

[quote author=wat72 link=topic=343063.msg2650633#msg2650633 date=1233509703]

Make a new command, then use System.out.println or the sendMessage method to printout the absX and absY integers.
[/quote]No, you should call integers variables.

No, they are intergers.
[/quote]Yes, but you call them variables because they are variables. Just like voids and anything else with brackets are called methods because they are methods.

Not everything with brackets is a method, and there’s no such thing as “voids”, void is a return type.
[/quote]No, void isn’t a return type it’s a non-primitive datatype, and datatypes with brackets are called methods. A void can’t be a return type because it doesn’t return anything.

void is a return type, it’s a return type of null. Also you clearly said,

and anything else with brackets are called methods

Which is false, because a class has brackets and a class is not a method.[/quote]I corrected myself and said that any datatype with brackets is called a method. A void “may” be a return type, but it’s also a non-primitive datatype.

Read full topic

and anything else with brackets are called methods
Which is false, because a class has brackets and a class is not a method.

item.title: Coords
item.dc:creator: @x_blitz_x x blitz x
item.description:
@x_blitz_x wrote:

Well, first you make a command. (I suggest you learn this bit first)

Then use the System.out.println like this,

System.out.println("X Coord: "+ absX);
System.out.println("Y Coord: "+ absY);
